contextOrdering.pl

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 =head1 NAME
00002 
00003 contextOrdering.pl - Parses ordered lists of letters like "B > A = C > D"
00004 
00005 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00006 
00007 This context provides a structured way to parse and check answers that
00008 are ordered lists of letters, where the letters are separated by
00009 greater-than signs or equal signs.  The only operators allowed are >
00010 and =, and the only letters allowed are the ones you specify explicitly.
00011 
00012 To access the context, you must include
00013 
00014     loadMacros("contextOrdering.pl");
00015 
00016 at the top of your problem file, and then specify the Ordering context:
00017 
00018     Context("Ordering");
00019 
00020 There are two main ways to use the Ordering context.  The first is to
00021 use the Ordering() command to generate your ordering.  This command
00022 creates a context in which the proper letters are defined, and returns
00023 a MathObject that represents the ordering you have provided.  For
00024 example,
00025 
00026     $ans = Ordering("B > A > C");
00027 
00028 or
00029 
00030     $ans = Ordering(A => 2, B => 2.5, C => 1);
00031 
00032 would both produce the same ordering.  The first form gives the
00033 ordering as the student must type it, and the second gives the
00034 ordering by specifying numeric values for the various letters that
00035 induce the resulting order.  Note that equality is determined using
00036 the default tolerances for the Ordering context.  You can change these
00037 using commands like the following:
00038 
00039     Context("Ordering");
00040     Context()->flags->set(tolerance => .01, tolType => 'absolute');
00041 
00042 If you want to allow lists of orderings, use the Ordering-List context:
00043 
00044     Context("Ordering-List");
00045     $ans = Ordering("A > B , B = C");
00046 
00047 Note that each Ordering() call uses its own copy of the current
00048 context.  If you need to modify the actual context used, then use the
00049 context() method of the resulting object.
00050 
00051 The second method of generating orderings is to declare the letters
00052 you wish to use explicitly, and then build the Ordering objects using
00053 the standard Compute() method:
00054 
00055     Context("Ordering");
00056     Letters("A","B","C","D");
00057     $a = Compute("A > B = C");
00058     $b = Compute("C > D");
00059 
00060 Note that in this case, D is still a valid letter that students can
00061 enter in response to an answer checker for $a, and similarly for A and
00062 B with $b.  Note also that both $a and $b use the same context, unlike
00063 orderings produced by calls to the Ordering() function.  Changes to
00064 the current context WILL affect $a and $b.
00065 
00066 If the ordering contains duplicate letters (e.g., "A > B > A"), then a
00067 warning message will be issued.  If not all the letters are used by
00068 the student, then that also produces a warning message.  The latter
00069 can be controlled by the showMissingLetterHints flag to the cmp()
00070 method.  For example:
00071 
00072     ANS(Ordering("A > B > C")->cmp(showMissingLetterHints => 0));
00073 
00074 would prevent the message from being issued if the student submitted
00075 just "A > B".
00076 
00077 =cut
00078 
00079 loadMacros("MathObjects.pl");
00080 
00081 sub _contextOrdering_init {context::Ordering::Init()}
00082 
00083 ###########################################
00084 #
00085 #  The main Ordering routines
00086 #
00087 
00088 package context::Ordering;
00089 
00090 #
00091 #  Here we set up the prototype contexts and define the needed
00092 #  functions in the main:: namespace.  Some error messages are
00093 #  modified to read better for these contexts.
00094 #
00095 sub Init {
00096   my $context = $main::context{Ordering} = Parser::Context->getCopy("Numeric");
00097   $context->{name} = "Ordering";
00098   $context->parens->clear();
00099   $context->variables->clear();
00100   $context->constants->clear();
00101   $context->operators->clear();
00102   $context->functions->clear();
00103   $context->strings->clear();
00104   $context->operators->add(
00105    '>' => {precedence => 1.5, associativity => 'left', type => 'bin', class => 'context::Ordering::BOP::ordering'},
00106    '=' => {precedence => 1.7, associativity => 'left', type => 'bin', class => 'context::Ordering::BOP::ordering'},
00107   );
00108   $context->{parser}{String}  = "context::Ordering::Parser::String";
00109   $context->{parser}{Value}   = "context::Ordering::Parser::Value";
00110   $context->{value}{String}   = "context::Ordering::Value::String";
00111   $context->{value}{Ordering} = "context::Ordering::Value::Ordering";
00112   $context->strings->add('='=>{hidden=>1},'>'=>{hidden=>1});
00113   $context->{error}{msg}{"Variable '%s' is not defined in this context"} = "'%s' is not defined in this context";
00114   $context->{error}{msg}{"Unexpected character '%s'"} = "Can't use '%s' in this context";
00115   $context->{error}{msg}{"Missing operand before '%s'"} = "Missing letter before '%s'";
00116   $context->{error}{msg}{"Missing operand after '%s'"} = "Missing letter after '%s'";
00117 
00118   $context = $main::context{'Ordering-List'} = $context->copy;
00119   $context->{name} = 'Ordering-List';
00120   $context->operators->redefine(',',from => "Full");
00121   $context->{value}{List} = "context::Ordering::Value::List";
00122 
00123   main::PG_restricted_eval('sub Letters {context::Ordering::Letters(@_)}');
00124   main::PG_restricted_eval('sub Ordering {context::Ordering::Ordering(@_)}');
00125 }
00126 
00127 #
00128 #  A routine to set the letters allowed in this context.
00129 #  (Old letters are cleared, and > and = are allowed, but hidden,
00130 #   since they are used in the List() objects that implement the context).
00131 #
00132 sub Letters {
00133   my $context = (Value::isContext($_[0]) ? shift : main::Context());
00134   my @strings;
00135   foreach my $x (@_) {push(@strings, $x => {isLetter => 1, caseSensitive => 1})}
00136   $context->strings->are(@strings);
00137   $context->strings->add('='=>{hidden=>1},'>'=>{hidden=>1});
00138 }
00139 
00140 #
00141 #  Create orderings from strings or lists of letter => value pairs.
00142 #  A copy of the current context is created that contains the proper
00143 #  letters, and the correct string is created and parsed into an
00144 #  Ordering object.
00145 #
00146 sub Ordering {
00147   my $context = main::Context()->copy; my $string;
00148   Value->Error("The current context is not the Ordering context")
00149     unless $context->{name} =~ m/Ordering/;
00150   if (scalar(@_) == 1) {
00151     $string = shift;
00152     my $letters = $string; $letters =~ s/ //g;
00153     context::Ordering::Letters($context,split(/[>=]/,$letters));
00154   } else {
00155     my %letter = @_; my @letters = keys %letter;
00156     context::Ordering::Letters($context,@letters);
00157     foreach my $x (@letters) {$letter{$x} = Value::Real->new($context,$letter{$x})}
00158     my @order = main::PGsort(
00159       sub {$letter{$_[0]} == $letter{$_[1]} ?  $_[0] lt $_[1] : $letter{$_[0]} > $letter{$_[1]}},
00160       @letters
00161     );
00162     my $a = shift(@order); my $b; $string = $a;
00163     while ($b = shift(@order)) {
00164       $string .= ($letter{$a} == $letter{$b} ? " = " : " > ") . $b;
00165       $a = $b;
00166     }
00167   }
00168   return main::Formula($context,$string)->eval;
00169 }
00170 
00171 #############################################################
00172 #
00173 #  This is a Parser BOP used to create the Ordering objects
00174 #  used internally.  They are actually lists with the operator
00175 #  and the two operands, and the comparisons is based on the
00176 #  standard list comparisons.  The operands are either the strings
00177 #  for individual letters, or another Ordering object as a
00178 #  nested List.
00179 #
00180 
00181 package context::Ordering::BOP::ordering;
00182 our @ISA = ('Parser::BOP');
00183 
00184 sub class {"Ordering"}
00185 
00186 sub isOrdering {
00187   my $self = shift; my $obj = shift; my $class = $obj->class;
00188   return $class eq 'Ordering' || $obj->{def}{isLetter};
00189 }
00190 
00191 sub _check {
00192   my $self = shift;
00193   $self->Error("Operands of %s must be letters",$self->{bop})
00194     unless $self->isOrdering($self->{lop}) && $self->isOrdering($self->{rop});
00195   $self->{letters} = $self->{lop}{letters}; # we modify {lop}{letters} this way, but that doesn't matter
00196   foreach my $x (keys %{$self->{rop}{letters}}) {
00197     if (defined($self->{letters}{$x})) {
00198       $self->{ref} = $self->{rop}{letters}{$x};
00199       $self->Error("Each letter may appear only once in an ordering");
00200     }
00201     $self->{letters}{$x} = $self->{rop}{letters}{$x};
00202   }
00203 }
00204 
00205 sub _eval {
00206   my $self = shift;
00207   my $ordering = $self->Package("Ordering")->new($self->context,$self->{bop},@_);
00208   $ordering->{letters} = $self->{letters};
00209   return $ordering;
00210 }
00211 
00212 sub string {
00213   my $self = shift;
00214   return $self->{lop}->string." ".$self->{bop}." ".$self->{rop}->string;
00215 }
00216 
00217 sub TeX {
00218   my $self = shift;
00219   return $self->{lop}->TeX." ".$self->{bop}." ".$self->{rop}->TeX;
00220 }
00221 
00222 
00223 #############################################################
00224 #
00225 #  This is the Value object used to implement the list That represents
00226 #  one ordering operation.  It is simply a normal Value::List with the
00227 #  operator as the first entry and the two operands as the remaing
00228 #  entries in the list.  The new() method is overriden to make binary
00229 #  trees of equal operators into flat sorted lists.  We override the
00230 #  List string and TeX methods so that they print correctly as binary
00231 #  operators.  The cmp_equal method is overriden to make sure the that
00232 #  the lists are treated as a unit during answer checking.  There is
00233 #  also a routine for adding letters to the object's context.
00234 #
00235 
00236 package context::Ordering::Value::Ordering;
00237 our @ISA = ('Value::List');
00238 
00239 #
00240 #  Put all equal letters into one list and sort them
00241 #
00242 sub new {
00243   my $self = shift;
00244   my $context = (Value::isContext($_[0]) ? shift : $self->context);
00245   my $bop = shift; my @letters = @_;
00246   if ($bop eq '=') {
00247     if (Value::classMatch($letters[0],'Ordering') && $letters[0]->{data}[0] eq '=')
00248       {@letters = ($letters[0]->value,$letters[1]); shift @letters}
00249     @letters = main::lex_sort(@letters);
00250   }
00251   return $self->SUPER::new($context,$bop,@letters);
00252 }
00253 
00254 sub string {
00255   my $self = shift;
00256   my ($bop,@rest) = $self->value;
00257   foreach my $x (@rest) {$x = $x->string};
00258   return join(" $bop ",@rest);
00259 }
00260 
00261 sub TeX {
00262   my $self = shift;
00263   my ($bop,@rest) = $self->value;
00264   foreach my $x (@rest) {$x = $x->TeX};
00265   return join(" $bop ",@rest);
00266 }
00267 
00268 #
00269 #  Make sure we do comparison as a list of lists (rather than as the
00270 #  individual entries in the underlying Value::List that encodes
00271 #  the ordering)
00272 #
00273 sub cmp_equal {
00274   my $self = shift; my $ans = $_[0];
00275   $ans->{typeMatch} = $ans->{firstElement} = $self;
00276   $ans->{correct_formula} = $self->{equation};
00277   $self = $ans->{correct_value} = Value::List->make($self);
00278   $ans->{student_value} = Value::List->make($ans->{student_value})
00279       if Value::classMatch($ans->{student_value},'Ordering');
00280   return $self->SUPER::cmp_equal(@_);
00281 }
00282 
00283 sub cmp_defaults {
00284   my $self = shift;
00285   return (
00286     $self->SUPER::cmp_defaults(@_),
00287     showMissingLetterHints => 1,
00288   );
00289 }
00290 
00291 sub cmp_postprocess {
00292   my $self = shift; my $ans = shift;
00293   return if $ans->{isPreview} || $ans->{score} != 0;
00294   $self->cmp_Error($ans,"Your ordering should include all the letters")
00295     if $ans->{showMissingLetterHints} &&
00296        scalar(keys %{$ans->{correct_formula}{tree}{letters}}) !=
00297        scalar(keys %{$ans->{student_formula}{tree}{letters}});
00298 }
00299 
00300 #
00301 #  Add more letters to the ordering's context (so student answers
00302 #  can include them even if they aren't in the correct answer).
00303 #
00304 sub AddLetters {
00305   my $self = shift; my $context = $self->context;
00306   my @strings;
00307   foreach my $x (@_) {
00308     push(@strings, $x => {isLetter => 1, caseSensitive => 1})
00309       unless $context->strings->get($x);
00310   }
00311   $context->strings->add(@strings) if scalar(@strings);
00312 }

00315 #
00316 #  This overrides the TeX method of the letters
00317 #  so that they don't print using the \rm font.
00318 #
00319 
00320 package context::Ordering::Value::String;
00321 our @ISA = ('Value::String');
00322 
00323 sub TeX {shift->value}

00326 #############################################################
00327 #
00328 #  Override Parser classes so that we can check for repeated letters
00329 #
00330 
00331 package context::Ordering::Parser::String;
00332 our @ISA = ('Parser::String');
00333 
00334 #
00335 #  Save the letters positional reference
00336 #
00337 sub new {
00338   my $self = shift;
00339   $self = $self->SUPER::new(@_);
00340   $self->{letters}{$self->{value}} = $self->{ref} if $self->{def}{isLetter};
00341   return $self;
00342 }

00346 package context::Ordering::Parser::Value;
00347 our @ISA = ('Parser::Value');
00348 
00349 #
00350 #  Move letters to Value object
00351 #
00352 sub new {
00353   my $self = shift;
00354   $self = $self->SUPER::new(@_);
00355   $self->{letters} = $self->{value}{letters} if defined $self->{value}{letters};
00356   return $self;
00357 }
00358 
00359 #
00360 #  Return Ordering class if the object is one
00361 #
00362 sub class {
00363   my $self = shift;
00364   return "Ordering" if $self->{value}->classMatch('Ordering');
00365   return $self->SUPER::class;
00366 }

00368 #############################################################
00369 #
00370 #  This overrides the cmp_equal method to make sure that
00371 #  Ordering lists are put into nested lists (since the
00372 #  underlying ordering is a list, we don't want the
00373 #  list checker to test the individual parts of the list,
00374 #  but rather the list as a whole).
00375 #
00376 
00377 package context::Ordering::Value::List;
00378 our @ISA = ('Value::List');
00379 
00380 sub cmp_equal {
00381   my $self = shift;  my $ans = $_[0];
00382   $ans->{student_value} = Value::List->make($ans->{student_value})
00383     if Value::classMatch($ans->{student_value},'Ordering');
00384   return $self->SUPER::cmp_equal(@_);
00385 }
